facts.text: Petitioner purchased 195.51 acres of land in the former Bhopal State from Babu Rehmatullah on June 23, 1950, for a consideration of Rs. 3,500.
Rehmatullah was declared to be an intending evacuee by the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property.
Rehmatullah left India for Pakistan on June 20, 1951.
On June 12, 1951, the Assistant Custodian issued a notice to the petitioner to show cause why the land should not be declared evacuee property.
After hearing the petitioner, the property was declared evacuee property on August 8, 1951.
Petitioner challenged the order in appeal and revision under the Act but was unsuccessful.
Writ petition before Judicial Commissioner, Bhopal, dismissed in limine on July 14, 1954.
Petitioner filed petition under Art. 32 before Supreme Court.
Petitioner applied to Custodian under s.40 for confirming the sale; rejected on ground that evacuee did not act in good faith.
Prior to sale to petitioner, Rehmatullah sold a house to some nurses for inadequate consideration, but that sale was confirmed by Custodian.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950, particularly s.2(d) and s.40(4), are unconstitutional as they enable taking away property without compensation under Art.31(2).
Whether Art.31(5)(b)(iii) protection is limited to laws that themselves declare property evacuee, not those empowering authority to declare.
Whether declaration of property as evacuee deprives petitioner without authority of law under Art.31(1).
Whether cls.(a) and (c) of s.40(4) confer arbitrary power on Custodian.
Whether petitioner discriminated against in confirmation of transaction compared to nurses' house sale.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Act, ss.2(d) and 40(4), unconstitutional as take away property without compensation per Art.31(2).
Art.31(5)(b)(iii) protection limited to law itself declaring property evacuee, not empowering authority.
Property not evacuee; declaration deprives without authority of law.
Cls.(a) and (c) of s.40(4) ultra vires as confer arbitrary power; 'good faith' vague; lacks standard; transferee good faith insufficient if evacuee not.
Discriminated against: Rehmatullah's prior house sale to nurses confirmed despite inadequate consideration, while petitioner's adequate sale not.

court_reasoning.text: Art.31(5)(b)(iii) protects laws made pursuant to agreements re evacuee property; includes laws laying criteria for declaration by authority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Protection not restricted as contended; extends to laws providing for determination of criteria.

court_reasoning.text: Declaration by Custodian pursuant to law is 'authority of law' under Art.31(1).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deprivation valid if by authority of law.

court_reasoning.text: S.40(4) confers judicial power to inquire into good faith; 'good faith' has definite meaning in courts of law; upheld in Rabia Bai case even if only evacuee lacked good faith.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not arbitrary; power judicial in nature.

court_reasoning.text: Custodian's order judicial; error in one case does not prove discrimination against petitioner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere difference in outcomes not discrimination.

holdings.text: Provisions of Evacuee Property Act, ss.2(d),40(4) constitutional under Art.31(5)(b)(iii); declaration valid authority of law.
S.40(4)(a) not ultra vires; good faith standard adequate for judicial inquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rabia Bai v. The Custodian-General of Evacuee Property
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld Custodian's refusal to confirm transfer where evacuee acted in bad faith, even without transferee's bad faith.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions for declaring and dealing with evacuee property; confirmation of transactions; upheld as constitutional.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.32 for petition; Art.31 protects property; sub-cl.(5)(b)(iii) exempts evacuee property laws from cl.(2).

outcome.summary: Petition under Art.32 dismissed; all contentions rejected; provisions of Evacuee Property Act constitutional; no deprivation without authority of law or discrimination.

key_quotes.text: 'Nothing in clause (2) shall affect ... the provisions of any law which the State may hereafter make- ... with respect to property declared by law to be evacuee property.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Art.31(5)(b)(iii) providing constitutional protection to evacuee laws.

key_quotes.text: The words 'property declared by law to be evacuee property' would necessarily include property which could be declared as evacuee property.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects narrow interpretation; extends protection to procedural laws.

key_quotes.text: The power conferred by sub-s.(4) of s.40 is in the nature of a judicial power and, therefore, the absence of a standard ... would not render the provision unconstitutional.
key_quotes.speaker: court
